<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the period of a pendulum. Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 125, 740, 359]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 380, 354, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[591, 381, 663, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 413, 675, 432]]<|/det|>
A pendulum labelled A has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 144, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
Adjust the length of the pendulum until the distance \(d\) measured from the bottom of the clamp to the centre of the bob is \(50.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 489, 918, 523]]<|/det|>
Explain how you used the metre rule and set square to measure the length \(d\) as accurately as possible. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 889, 920, 907]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Displace the bob slightly and release it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 593, 136]]<|/det|>
Measure the time \(t_{1}\) for 10 complete oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[573, 163, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<form>t_1 = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 195, 181, 213]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 195, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
Calculate the period \(T_{1}\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 318, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<form>T_1 = ........................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 144, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 591, 368]]<|/det|>
Adjust the pendulum until the distance \(d\) is 100.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[573, 427, 917, 447]]<|/det|>
<form>t_2 = ...........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 488, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<form>T_2 = ...........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 535, 146, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 535, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
Remove the pendulum from the clamp. Using the balance provided, measure the mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the pendulum. The mass includes the pendulum bob and the thread.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 583, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<form>m_{\mathrm{A}} = ......................................................... g [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 613, 144, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 630, 631]]<|/det|>
Using the balance, measure the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of pendulum B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 644, 920, 663]]<|/det|>
<form>m_{\mathrm{B}} = ......................................................... g [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate how the potential difference across a resistance wire varies with the length of the wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 576, 137]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 147, 806, 361]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 383, 532, 401]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 144, 433]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 282, 463]]<|/det|> * Switch on. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 871, 495]]<|/det|> * Place the sliding contact C on the resistance wire at a distance \(l = 10.0 \text{cm}\) from B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 508, 918, 541]]<|/det|> * Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the potential difference \(V\) across the length \(l\) of the resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 688, 572]]<|/det|> * Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 777, 604]]<|/det|> * Repeat the procedure using \(l = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 617, 282, 634]]<|/det|> * Switch off. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 648, 539, 666]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 679, 764, 865]]<|/det|>
\(l/\mathrm {cm}\)\(V/V\)\(I/\mathrm {A}\)
10.0
30.0
50.0
70.0
90.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|> [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 848, 92]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (y-axis) against \(l / \text{cm}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0).

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 485, 920, 520]]<|/det|>

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 794, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate some thermal properties of sand and water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 571, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 139, 853, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 438, 532, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 146, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 613, 489]]<|/det|>
Use the thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{S}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 515, 917, 535]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{S}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 547, 829, 566]]<|/det|>
Use the thermometer to measure the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water in beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 579, 920, 598]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 594, 920, 612]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 624, 146, 643]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 624, 920, 657]]<|/det|>
Beaker A contains sand. Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water from beaker B into beaker A. Carefully stir the water and sand mixture.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 670, 571, 689]]<|/det|>
Record the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 701, 920, 720]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 701, 920, 720]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 868, 91]]<|/det|>
Calculate the rise in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the sand using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{M}} - \theta_{\mathrm{S}})\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 134, 917, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{\mathrm{R}} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 166, 897, 186]]<|/det|>
Calculate the fall in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 230, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 262, 181, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 255, 589, 285]]<|/det|>
Calculate the ratio \(S\) using the equation \(S = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{R}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{F}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 339, 920, 359]]<|/det|>
<form>S = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 146, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 373, 645, 392]]<|/det|>
Measure the new temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water supplied.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 419, 920, 439]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 144, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 451, 920, 485]]<|/det|>
Beaker C contains water at room temperature. Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into beaker C. Carefully stir the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 496, 569, 516]]<|/det|>
Record the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 528, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 559, 141, 578]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
Calculate the rise in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the cold water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{M}} - \theta_{\mathrm{S}})\). Use the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{S}}\) recorded in **(a)** and the value of \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) recorded in **(e)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 638, 918, 658]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 669, 920, 704]]<|/det|>
Calculate the fall in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\). Use the value of \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) from **(d)** and \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) from **(e)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 750, 918, 769]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} =\) .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 777, 561, 804]]<|/det|>
Calculate the ratio \(W\) using the equation \(W = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{R}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{F}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 845, 920, 864]]<|/det|>
<form>\(W =\) .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the bending of \(1 \text{m}\) length strips of different materials. She compares how far they bend when loaded at one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the material from which the strips are made affects the bending of the strips when loaded at one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 526, 182]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 537, 213]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 576, 244]]<|/det|>
strips of wood, plastic, steel and aluminium, all \(1 \text{m}\) long

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 312, 258]]<|/det|>
a set of slotted masses

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 222, 273]]<|/det|>
a metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 606, 290]]<|/det|>
a G-clamp (used to hold the strips to the laboratory bench).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 740, 320]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 324, 352]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 636, 382]]<|/det|>
â€¢ draw a diagram to show the arrangement of the apparatus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
â€¢ explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements you would take

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 507, 460]]<|/det|>
â€¢ state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
â€¢ draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 656, 537]]<|/det|>
â€¢ explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion.
